prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CGCG 049-057: Band-9 imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our main science goal is to obtain a high resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and 450 micron dust continuum in the nuclear region of the starburst galaxy CGCG 049-057 with the 0.12" beam (corresponding to ~38 pc at the distance of the galaxy). For this particular galaxy, the nuclear structure is dominated by a circumnuclear disk of 1"x2" (or 316 x 633 pc), revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST observation of a resolution of ~0.2" (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2002, AJ, 124, 166). In order to fully recover all the structures up to the size of the circumnuclear disk, we also require an LAS of ~2.5". As a result, the ALMA OT recommends an additional coarser array configuration to be included as part of this observation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require that the observation shall have S/N > 10 for the expected average flux density of the CO (6-5) line emission per beam of 0.12" over a velocity bin of in 30 km/s.
We estimated a conservative line flux sensitivity per beam pf 0.12" as follows: The VLA 1.4GHz continuum map (Condon et al. 1990, ApJS, 73, 359) infers a seize of < 2". So all the CO(6-5) line flux we detected with Herschel SPIRE/FTS (Lu et al. 2014, ApJ, 787, L23) comes largely from a region < 2", which is roughly the same size as the circumnuclear disk of 1"x2" (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006, ApJ, 650, 835). We assumed conservatively (a) that 70% of the total CO(6-5) flux, given in Table 1, is within this nuclear disk with an area filling factor of 50%, and (b) that the velocity dispersion is 250 km/s, close to that observed in the CO(1-0) observation (Sanders et al. 1991, ApJ, 370, 158). (Note: the Herschel FTS, with a lower spectral resolution, did not resolve the line.) Under these reasonable assumptions, the expected average surface brightness is 40.8 mJy/beam in the 0.12" beam configuration. Therefore, to achieve a S/N = 10, the desired sensitivity per pointing is 4.08 mJy/beam over a velocity bin of 30 km/s. According to ALMA OT, this requires ~23 min integration for this configuration. The corresponding continuum observations using the other 3 basebands, which have sensitivities of 1 sigma ~ 0.39 mJy/beam, results in S/N > 41.

We use one baseband for our trageted CO(6-5) line observation, and the other 3 basebands to measure the continuum on both sides of the CO(6-5) line. We chose the lowest spectral resolution (13 km/s) correlator configuration as it is adequate for our science goal (as the expected CO(6-5) line width is much wider, at ~250 km.s), and at the same time, offers better S/N for us.

Our main science goal of this proposal is to map the CO (6-5) line emission down to a linear scale of 50 pc (or less), the typical size of GMCs, for all our chosen targets for this program. All our targets are at similar distances, and our linear resolution requirement can be acheieved with a beam of 0.12" for all our fine-resolution observations in this proposal.
However, this particular target shows a circumnuclear disk of 1" x 2". In order to recover the structures up to the size of this nuclear disk, our required LAS is to be ~2.5". The ALMA Cycle-3 OT recommends that one additional (coarser) array configuration will be included as part of this observation, with an extra integration time of ~28 min.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IC 5179: Band-9 imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to obtain a high resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and 450 micron dust continuum over the central ~1" area in the nuclear region of the starburst galaxy IC 5179 with the 0.12" beam (corresponding to ~30 pc at the distance of the galaxy). This enables us to detail gas distribution within the compact nuclear core of < 1", revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation of comparable angular resolution (of a resolution of 0.2") (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006, ApJ, 650, 835). Our required LAS i stherefore 1".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require that the observation shall have S/N >10 for the anticipated average surface brightness of the CO(6-5) emission over a velcoity bin of 30 km/s.
We estimated a conservative line flux density per beam of 0.12" as follows: The Spitzer 8 um image shows that about 65% of the 8 um flux is within the HST field of view (19.5"x19.5") of the Paschen-alpha line emission observation of Alonso-Herrero et al. (2006, ApJ, 650, 835). This means that more than 65% of the Herschel detected CO(6-5) flux (Lu et al. 2014, ApJ, 787, L23) should originate from within this HST field of view, within which about 50% of the Paschen-alpha flux is from the central compact core of size < 1" (see Alonso-Herrero et al 2006). On the other hand, the less dust extinction-affected, high angular resolution (0.4") image at 8 micron (Diaz-Santo et al. 2008, ApJ, 685, 211) suggests that the CO(6-5) flux should be significantly more concentrated in the nuclear core. As a result, it is conservative to assume that 50% of the Hersche-detected CO(6-5) flux, given in Table 1 in the proposal text, is from this compact nuclear core of <1" in diameter. We assume further (a) an area filling factor of 50%, and (b) that the velocity dispersion is 250 km/s, close to that found in the CO(1-0) observation (Garay et al. 1993, A&A, 277, 405). (Note: the Herschel SPIRE/FTS, with a lower spectral resolution, did not resolve the line.) Under these reasonable assumptions, the expected average surface brightness is 46.3 mJy/beam for the 0.12" beam. According to ALMA OT, this requires ~17 min on-target integration. The corresponding continuum observation, using the other 3 basebands, shall reach an rms sensitivity of 0.44 mJy/beam. This results in S/N > 42.

We use one baseband for our targeted CO(6-5) line observation, and the other 3 basebands to measure the continuum on both sides of the CO(6-5) line. We chose the lowest spectral resolution (13 km/s) correlator configuration as it is adequate for our science goal (as the expected CO(6-5) line width is much wider, at ~250 km/s), and at the same time, offers better S/N.

Our main science goal of this proposal is to map the CO(6-5) line emission down to a linear scale of 50 pc (or less), the typical size of GMC, for all our chosen targets for this program. All our targets are at similar distances, and our linear resolution requirement can be met with a beam of 0.12" for all our fine-resolution observations in this proposal.
For this particular galaxy, the nuclear structure is dominated by a compact core of < 1" in diameter. We therefore ask for LAS = 1". The ALMA OT recommend no additional coarser array configuration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC 5135: Band-9 imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our main science goal is to obtain a high resolution map of the CO(6-5) line emission and the 450 micron dust continuum in the nuclear region of the Seyfert 2 galaxy NGC 5135 with the 0.12" beam (corresponding to ~35 pc at the distance of the galaxy) in Band 9. For this particular galaxy, the nuclear structure is dominated by a circumnuclear disk of 2"x2.5" in size as revealed in the Paschen-alpha line emission from an HST imaging observation of a resolution of ~0.2" (Alonso-Herrero et al. 2006, ApJ, 650, 835). In order to fully recover all the structures uo to the size of the circumnuclear disk, we also require the LAS tio be ~2.5". As a result, the ALMA OT recoomends an additional coarser array configuration to be part of this observation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require that the observation shall have S/N > 10 for the expected average surface brightness of the CO J=6-5 emission over a velocity bin of 15 km/s.
We estimate a conservative line flux density per beam as follows: The VLA 1.4 GHz (Condo et al. 1996, ApJS, 103, 81) infers a size of ~6"x6". So all the CO(6-5) flux we detected in our Herschel SPIRE/FTS observation (Lu et al. 2014, ApJ, 787, L23) shall originate mostly from within the HST field of view (19.5"x19.5") of the Paschen-alpha line observation of Alonso-Herrero et al (2006, ApJ, 650, 835), in which they show that most of Paschen-alpha emission is limited to the circumnuclear disk/ring of ~ 2"x2.5". This is confirmed by the high resolution (0.4") 8 micron image of Diaz-Santos et al (2008, ApJ, 685, 211). We therefore assumed conservatively (a) that 70% of the total CO(6-5) flux, given in Table 1, is within this nuclear disk with an area filling fraction of 50%, and (b) that the velocity dispersion is 150 km/s, close to that found in the CO(1-0) observation (Gao & Solomom 2004, ApJS, 152, 63). (Note: The Herschel SPIRE/FTS, with a lower spectral resolution, did not resolved the line.) Under these REASONABLE assumptions, the average surface brightness is 57.7 mJy/beam in the 0.12" beam configuration. According to ALMA OT, this requires 17.6 min integration. The corresponding continuum observation, using the other 3 basebands, shall reach an rms sensitivity of 0.39 mJy/beam, resulting in S/N > 26.

We use one baseband for our targeted CO(6-5) line observation, and the other 3 basebands to measure the continuum on both sides of the CO(6-5) line. We chose the lowest spectral resolution (13 km/s) correlator configuration as it is adequate for our science goal (as the expected CO(6-5) line width is on the order of 150 km/s), and at the same time, offers better S/N for us. (Note: our S/N requirement calculation was based on a velocity bin of 15 km/s in this particular case in view of the narrower velocitu width of this target.)

Our main science goal of this proposal is to map the CO(6-5) line emission down to a linear scale of 50 pc (or less), the typical size of GMCs, for all our chosen targets in this proposal. All our targets are at similar distances, and our linear resolution requirement can be achieved with a beam of 0.12" for all our fine-resolution observations in this proposal.
However, this particular target shows a circumnuclear disk of 1.5" x 2.5". In order to recover the structures up to the size of this circumnuclear disk, our required LAS is to be 2.5". The ALMA Cycle-3 OT recommends that one additional (coarser) array configuration is to be included as part of this observation, with an extra integration time of 23.5 min.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA mapping in Band-9 at 0.12"/beam of the CO(6-5) line emission and the 450 um dust continuum in the nuclei of 3 luminous IR galaxies (LIRGs), to complete our Cycle-2 program (Category-B priority) to characterize the nuclear dense molecular gas distributions in a set of 4 LIRGs at resolutions < 50 pc, characteristic size of GMCs. These targets were carefully chosen to represent the diversity of LIRGs, including 2 starbursts and 2 AGNs and representing two most common nuclear configurations: two taregts with a compact nuclear core of < 1" (< 300 pc) and two with a circumnuclear disk of 2" to 2.5" (500 to 1000 pc) in diameter. For the latter two, we also request a coarser array configuration to recover the structures associated with their nuclear disk. The ALMA results are crucial in determining physical gas/dust conditions in different nuclear configurations, spatial correlation between CO(6-5) and Pa-alpha emissions, the role AGN plays in gas heating and feedback, and if nuclear dense molecular gas remains in discrete GMCs or is compressed into spatially continuous molecular gas over scales much larger than 50 pc.
